text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen so today i 
have yet another dish that is worthy of

the hot thai label yes we are making hot thai 
tuna so i love canned tuna it's such a humble

versatile accessible ingredient that anybody has 
and it's great for a weeknight when you haven't

thought much of anything to do but today 
i'm going to take this humble tuna and turn

it into something incredibly flavorful that is 
bursting with thai flavors i mean this thing is so

flavorful that a little goes a long way i've been 
eating it pretty much almost every day this week

just toss with jasmine rice it's great on kanji 
put it in an omelette so versatile lasts a long

time in your fridge i mean this this is 
hot thai tuna right here let's get started

so this dish is actually inspired by a 
southern thai dish called kua gling which

i have a recipe i'll link to below so the first 
thing we're going to make is a curry paste that

is a southern style curry paste which is easy 
to do if you already have red curry paste

store-bought homemade adding a few ingredients and 
make it southern first one being black pepper yes

most of the time in thai cuisine we use white 
pepper but in the south black pepper comes up

a lot more so we're going to grind that down 
if you have a grinder you can use a grinder

okay so now once it's nice and fine i'm 
gonna add the other iconically southern

thai ingredient and that is turmeric so 
you can use dry powder turmeric for this

but if you have fresh even better one tip 
about turmeric you don't have to peel it if

you're going to grind it up into a paste just 
wash it really well and then just slice it up

you won't notice any difference at all so you 
want to grind that down into a paste as well

turmeric just smells healthy you smell this 
and you're like this is going to be good for me

okay and then i'm going to add extra shrimp paste 
because in the south they also like to use a lot

of shrimp paste fermented shrimp paste you don't 
have to but because i'm adding shrimp paste i'm

not gonna need to add any more fish sauce in the 
recipe if you're not gonna do shrimp paste you

might need to add some more fish sauce later on 
just gonna pound to mix oh i never showed you what

this looks like there you go you wanted a nice 
paste and i'm just gonna mix the shrimp paste in

and then that's it now in goes my red 
curry paste there we go and just mix

and that is it shortcut southern curry paste we're 
almost ready to cook but i want to show you how i

slice this other important ingredient this magrude 
lime leaves gonna add that nice citrusy freshness

if you don't have it not a big deal but i 
recommend adding it if you have some and

i just want to show you how i slice it because 
it's really important to get this fine because

these are really tough and if you don't get it 
fine it'll be in your teeth everywhere it's not

comfortable so roll it up you can have them if 
you'd like if there are big stems i didn't see any

big stems on here but sometimes this stem in the 
middle is quite thick so you just pull that off

but if it's a thin stem then it's not a big deal 
roll it back up and then as finely as you can
you want to slice it you cannot go too fine

but you can go too coarse like 
i'm actually not very good at this

there are people who get it much finer than me 
but i get it enough that it's not uncomfortable

so the knife should be against your knuckle at 
all times you should be just really having to push

to get the knife moving and that's how 
you get tiny tiny tiny movement if your

the knife is not pushing against your knuckle 
it's really easy to just get a big julien see

that's pretty good okay let's get cooking before 
we move on we need to talk about this pan so

this is pan from mizen who is our sponsor 
today so mizen sells premium kitchen tools

at affordable prices because they sell direct 
to consumers now i've been using this pen for a

little while and so far i love it and i'm not just 
saying that because they're sponsoring the show

so the key to a good stainless steel skillet there 
are two things the weight and the material this

pan is a five ply pan it is heavy like you pick 
it up and this is a heavy pan and that's going to

help distribute heat evenly and also for heat to 
retain longer now the material the core of this is

aluminum which is an excellent heat conductor but 
the exterior is stainless steel which is durable

and also retains heat longer now this is a 10 inch 
skillet but most 10 inch skillets actually only

have eight inches of cooking surface but nissan 
designed it so that it's 19 larger which is super

handy because overcrowding food is never a good 
thing i've been making steaks on here searing

vegetables and i can crank the heat to max and 
get really nice browning on it it is dishwasher

safe oven safe up to 500 degrees and yes it 
works on induction this thing is pretty much

indestructible and it'll last you a lifetime misen 
cost less than half of the premium brand so it's

a really good value for your money and on top of 
that they're offering a discount for my followers

so if you click the link in the description and 
use the code pylon's kitchen to get 20 off your

first order again the code is pylon's kitchen 
for 20 off your first order i'm gonna start with

uh sauteing the curry paste and be a little bit 
generous with oil if your tuna was packed in water

because it's absolutely lean right like there's 
nothing no oil no fat and anything so if you

don't put enough oil it's going to be a little 
dry i need a something to cook with my goodness

excuse me i'm new here so 
i want to get that sauteing

keep the heat sort of low medium low at this 
point because curry paste burns pretty quickly

yeah and there should be plenty of oil 
for the curry paste to swim in here

okay this is super easy you've got your 
oh i need to add some palm sugar some

palm sugar you need that sweetness 
to balance out all the saltiness

and the spiciness and you want to add the palm 
sugar earlier so that it has time to dissolve

you can smell it already the tuna goes in so i've 
got two cans of tuna here the only tip that i'm

going to give you with the tuna make sure it's 
sustainably caught tuna it's incredibly important

um when tuna is not caught well it's extremely 
destructive so check the can now most of the time

at any grocery store you can find cans 
of tuna that says sustainably caught

or some indication that they are responsible 
fishers and no salt added oh yeah that's the other

very important thing because you want all the 
salt to come from either fish sauce shrimp paste

or whatever salt is in the curry paste already 
if the tuna itself is salty you're really limited

because this is flavorful and now all you have 
to do is cook this until it's dry the end result

that we're going for here is sort of like this 
dry crumbly tuna mix that you can just put toss

with your rice again top with congee it's one 
of my favorite ways to have it and so you don't

want this moist and wet and soggy you want it to 
kind of split apart a little bit okay so now that

it's ah smells so good i smelled that too close 
spicy um maybe don't put your face over the log

okay now i'm going to add some freshness some 
freshly sliced lemongrass which you also want

to slice thinly for the same reason as the lime 
leaves and the lime leaves go in and i'm going

to just toss that briefly and then it's pretty 
much done because you want those things fresh now

if you've never made this before you need to taste 
this and add fish sauce to taste my curry paste is

already salty i added shrimp paste so this i know 
i've made it a few times is already where it needs

to be but if it's your first time absolutely you 
need to taste it and before we finish i'm because

you guys are hardcore now i am going to introduce 
you to the concept of look dot this is new i've

never done this before in hot thai kitchen but 
look dot in thai in thai cuisine anyway refers to

whole or big chunks of chilies that you just 
throw into the dish and it's sort of like

landmines and the idea is that you're adding 
them whole so it's not going to make the dish

any spicier but when you're sharing the dish with 
people there's some people going to want it more

spicy so some people are going to want to just eat 
those chilis and yes some thai people actually eat

a whole chili and so the term for these whole 
landmine chili land mines are lukdot so we're

going to add some of that in i'm not going to eat 
them but it also looks a lot nicer you can do bell

peppers or whatever if you want and that is it 
how easy is that it smells so thai i feel like

anything with the lime leaves in it just instantly 
smells thai and again this will last in the fridge

for like i i think i had it for a couple of 
weeks and it was still good because there's

lots of chilies in there which is a preservative 
it's quite salty which also helps preserve things

so it's just a useful thing to have okay enough 
plating let's eat i'm hungry and as much as i

was talking passionately about luke dot i am 
not going to have any it's just as a demo wow
you didn't know tuna for taste like that

it's everything that i think about 
when i think of thai food fierce

bold flavors a lot of heat but also really 
aromatic a touch of sweetness that we added

you can't barely tell but it makes this well 
balanced it's salty which means this is something

that you definitely want to be tossing with rice 
this is like kanji i keep saying kanji because

it really is the best thing to put on kanji but 
you need something to mellow that out that firm

texture of the tuna is nice and chewy and you know 
what just for you i'm going to eat a look dote

and see how i do shall i do it 
okay let's try a green one okay

is that worse i don't know i don't know 
if this is worse or better and chili's fyi

it's really hard to predict from batch to 
batch even from plant to plant some of them

are just spicy some of them are just not 
so fingers crossed that this isn't too much

maybe i'll do half yeah half seems like a safer 
way to go that's more like two-thirds but that's
okay
you know i got lucky

it's not that bad don't get me wrong it is spicy 
but i think it could have been worse but also

chilis have a flavor especially green 
chilies have this sort of grassy flavor

and and it really if you can 
handle the heat it really

adds something adds another dimension another 
flavor to the dish so if you can handle it i think

it's a it's not a bad addition in fact i'm going 
to take one more bite and then pass out afterwards

hmm wow so the recipe as always will be on hot 
thaikitchen.com hold on let me start this one

no we're not trying the right one it's it's

so let's get this over with

the recipe as always will be on
